Award.AwardTitle: Gatekeeper Chromatin and Meiotic Commitment In Yeast

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The commitment to differentiate into new cell types is a crucial step in the development of animals, plants and many other eukaryotes. This project will study how this important process is regulated using yeast as the model system, and will uncover new mechanisms for controlling cell fate decisions. The project will also expand the pool of talented students who will pursue careers in science by exposing gifted students from a magnet high school to the process of scientific discovery; providing college students between their junior and senior year with hands-on research opportunities; and training graduate students in hypothesis-driven molecular genetic research.

Similar to differentiation programs in multicellular organisms, sporulation in yeast is governed by a transcriptional cascade. The transcriptional cascade of sporulation consists of early, middle and late sets of genes. Commitment to sporulation is not acquired until middle genes are expressed. Ndt80 is the transcription factor that activates middle promoters, and it is transcribed just before middle genes are expressed. The NDT80 promoter can be viewed as a platform where a switch-like output is generated that commits cells to gametogenesis. Studies performed in this laboratory indicate that the NDT80 promoter is assembled into a state resembling silenced heterochromatin specifically during meiotic development. This heterochromatic state (referred to as "gatekeeper chromatin") requires a DNA-binding repressor protein named Sum1 that recruits a histone deacetylase named Hst1 (a close relative of Sir2). At the end of meiotic G2 (just prior to the commitment point) Sum1 is phosphorylated on multiple residues by a cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK), and a meiosis-specific CDK-like kinase named Ime2. A central hypothesis that will be tested in this project is that the phosphorylation of Sum1 downregulates the Hst1 sirtuin to trigger the transition of heterochromatic gatekeeper chromatin to a state in which Sum1 is exchangeable with DNA. The resulting fractional occupancy of the Sum1 repressor permits low-level NDT80 expression. Commitment is acquired when newly translated Ndt80 protein competitively displaces Sum1 from DNA to initiate a positive autoregulatory loop (Sum1 and Ndt80 competitively bind to a single DNA element in the NDT80 promoter). In this project, this "gatekeeper chromatin model" for commitment will be tested. The specific goals of the project are 1) To establish an assay to monitor the exchangeability of the Sum1 protein in chromatin and 2) to combine sum1 phosphosite mutants and analog-sensitive kinases to create a system that synchronously undergoes the off/on gatekeeper chromatin transition at NDT80 in response to specific phosphomodifications, and to use this system to define biochemical steps controlling this transition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Meiotic development is essential for the continuity of almost all forms of eukaryotic life. In almost all cases, meiosis is induced by signals that trigger transcriptional cascades that in turn lead to the production of meiosis-specific proteins as they are needed. Following induction of meiosis, cells replicate the genome to produce differentiated pairs of homologous chromosomes that align with each other and undergo exchange (genetic recombination). Chromosomes are then segregated in a meiosis-specific reductional division (MI) that is followed by a mitosis-like equational (MII) division. The end products of meiotic development are haploid cells (sperm or eggs in animals) that are specialized for sexual fusion. Meiosis is therefore essential for genetic diversity and the life cycles of almost all organisms. Understanding meiosis and how it is regulated has implications for agricuture and it is also important for understanding causes of infertility and birth defects in humans.   

This award was to study the processes that control meiotic commitment, the key step after which the "decision" to complete meiosis becomes irreversible. The model system that was used is the experimentally tractable yeast, Saccharomyces cerevisiae. In preliminary data, we demonstrated that meiotic commitment is controlled by a single site in the genome (the NDT80 promoter) that controls whether the Ndt80 protein is produced. Once active Ndt80 is produced it activates the expression of genes required for chromosome segregation and completion of meiotic development. We refer to this genomic site as the meiotic "commitment site". We furthermore showed that a transcriptional repressor named Sum1 binds to the commitment site and prevents meiosis by complexing with other proteins/enzymes and forming a non-exchangeable chromatin structure (a heterochromatic state). This award supported studies that demonstrated that meiotic commitment is controlled by signaling molecules that modify the Sum1 complex and convert it from a non-exhangeable form to a form that follows standard equilibrium binding interactions with chromatin and is therefore exchangeable. Exchangeability permits a low level of NDT80 mRNA to be produced. Once this mRNA is translated, the Ndt80 protein, which binds to the same DNA site as that bound by Sum1, competitively displaces Sum1. This leads to activation of the NDT80 promoter. The Ndt80 protein that is produced and the positive autoregulatory loop therefore explain the switch-like behavior and irreversibility of meiotic commitment. We developed a set of genetic tools to study this transition and we also generated a system that allows the commitment switch to be controlled by cell permeable inhibitors of the protein kinases that modify Sum1.  This progress has defined novel regulatory modifications that control the commitment swicth and set the stage to define the biochemical/molecular basis of commitment. These studies are relevant to meiotic commitment and they are also relevant to the acquisition of commitment in other developmental programs.

In addition to the research activities described above, we also partnered with the science department of a public magnate school in the Philadelphia School District (The Julia R. Masterman School) to provide research internship opportunities for high school students. This activity provided opportunities for students to experience the process of scientific discovery while also contributing to the scientific goals of the project. We also partnered with the chair of the Biology Department at Rosemont College, a small college in Philadelphia, to increase the exposure of faculty and students to molecular/genetic research while also contributing to the scientific goals of the project. It is well established that internship/research opportunities are the most effective mechanism to increase the diversity and competitiveness of the scientific work force. These activities contributed towards this important goal by focusing on the next generation of scientists.
